title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) – In a deafening, deafening silence, the King stood alone. With the Chicago Bulls poised to steal a road victory, all noise ceased, all breath held, and all eyes fell upon Michael Jordan. And with the weight of a dynasty on his shoulders, His Airness delivered one final, iconic moment in a Seattle uniform.

It was not enough.

In a heart-stopping 91-90 thriller, the Seattle SuperSonics emerged victorious, but the night belonged to one man: Gary Payton. The Glove was not just worn; it was weaponized. Payton authored a historic performance, pouring in a staggering **41 points** and dishing out 8 assists, personally wrestling control from the mighty Bulls time and again.

The Sonics, fueled by Payton’s virtuoso scoring, built a lead that felt insurmountable. Yet, true to their championship pedigree, the Bulls clawed back. Scottie Pippen’s all-around brilliance and a late surge put Chicago ahead 90-89 in the game's final, frantic seconds.

But the night’s script was written by, and for, Payton. Isolating against relentless defensive pressure, he drove the lane with a defender clinging to him, drawing the foul with mere ticks remaining. Stepping to the line with the season hanging in the balance, The Glove was ice. Swish. Swish.

His two free throws sealed his masterpiece and the win, a crowning achievement in a career defined by gritty excellence. While the Bulls’ collective effort fell painfully short, they were merely witnesses to a force of nature. On this night, in a battle of titans, Gary Payton didn't just beat the Bulls. He authored a legend.
